Primary Indication: Colic, diarrhea, abdominal pain, digestive disorders
Technique: Acupressure ONLY, gentle clockwise massage, or indirect moxa on salt/ginger
SAFETY WARNINGS: â›” ABSOLUTE CONTRAINDICATION: Never needle CV 8 in any age. Acupressure or moxa only. Risk of peritonitis if needled.

Location Description: On midline, midway between navel and sternum base
Primary Indication: Poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, epigastric pain, indigestion
Age Recommendations: Age 2+ for needling; acupressure for infants
Needling Depth: Infant: acupressure only; Child 2-6: 0.2-0.3 inch; Child 6-12: 0.3-0.5 inch; Teen: 0.5-0.8 inch
Technique: Perpendicular insertion, gentle technique, or acupressure with circular motion
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ CAUTION: Shallow needling only. Avoid in infants under 2 years. Never needle deeply - organ damage risk.

Location Description: 3 cun below knee, 1 finger width lateral to tibia crest
Primary Indication: General tonic, digestive disorders, constipation, diarrhea, immune support, fatigue
Age Recommendations: Age 2+ for full use; gentle stimulation for younger
Needling Depth: Infant: acupressure; Child 2-6: 0.3-0.4 inch; Child 6-12: 0.5-0.7 inch; Teen: 0.7-1 inch
Technique: Perpendicular or slightly oblique insertion; can use moxa, acupressure, or laser
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ SAFE POINT for all ages when properly used. One of safest pediatric points. Minimum age 2 years for immune strengthening protocols.

Location Description: 3 cun above medial malleolus, posterior to tibia border
Primary Indication: Digestive disorders, insomnia, anxiety, bed-wetting, general tonic
Age Recommendations: Age 3+; avoid in infants and toddlers
Needling Depth: Child 3-6: 0.2-0.4 inch; Child 6-12: 0.4-0.6 inch; Teen: 0.6-0.8 inch
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ CAUTION: Avoid needling in children under 3 years. Traditional contraindication during pregnancy (not relevant for pediatrics but note for practitioners).

Location Description: 6 cun lateral to midline, first intercostal space, below clavicle
Primary Indication: Asthma, cough, chest congestion, breathing difficulty, chronic respiratory issues
Age Recommendations: Age 4+ for needling; acupressure for younger
Needling Depth: Child 4-8: 0.2-0.3 inch OBLIQUE; Child 8-12: 0.3-0.5 inch OBLIQUE; Teen: 0.4-0.6 inch OBLIQUE
Technique: OBLIQUE insertion medially and downward - NEVER perpendicular. Can use acupressure or laser
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ HIGH RISK: Pneumothorax risk if needled perpendicularly. Always oblique insertion. Prefer non-needle methods in young children.

Location Description: Below clavicle, 6 cun lateral to midline, in depression
Primary Indication: Cough, asthma, chest pain, shoulder pain, breathing issues
Age Recommendations: Age 6+ for needling; acupressure for younger
Needling Depth: Child 6-12: 0.2-0.3 inch OBLIQUE; Teen: 0.3-0.5 inch OBLIQUE
Technique: OBLIQUE insertion downward and medially - NEVER perpendicular
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ HIGH RISK: Pneumothorax danger. Oblique needling mandatory. Shallow depth only. Prefer acupressure in children under 8.

Location Description: On midline of sternum, level with 4th intercostal space, between nipples
Primary Indication: Asthma, cough, chest congestion, anxiety, breast milk insufficiency (mothers)
Age Recommendations: Age 4+ for needling; acupressure for younger
Needling Depth: Child 4-8: 0.15-0.25 inch; Child 8-12: 0.25-0.4 inch; Teen: 0.3-0.5 inch
Technique: Subcutaneous oblique insertion downward or horizontal threading. Acupressure safe for all ages
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ CAUTION: Shallow subcutaneous needling only. Risk of puncturing pleura if too deep. Gentle technique essential.

Location Description: 1.5 cun lateral to lower border of T3 spinous process
Primary Indication: Asthma, cough, chronic lung disease, respiratory support
Age Recommendations: Age 6+ for minimal needling; prefer non-needle methods
Needling Depth: Child 6-12: 0.15-0.25 inch PERPENDICULAR; Teen: 0.25-0.4 inch PERPENDICULAR
Technique: Perpendicular insertion, MINIMAL depth 2-3mm maximum for young children
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ HIGH RISK: Pneumothorax danger. MINIMAL needling only in children - depth 2-3mm maximum. Prefer moxa, acupressure, or laser therapy. Never needle deeply.

Location Description: Ulnar side of wrist crease, in depression radial to flexor carpi ulnaris tendon
Primary Indication: Insomnia, anxiety, fear, palpitations, emotional disturbance, ADHD symptoms
Needling Depth: Infant: acupressure; Child 3-8: 0.15-0.25 inch; Child 8-12: 0.25-0.4 inch; Teen: 0.3-0.5 inch
Technique: Perpendicular insertion or acupressure with gentle pressure for 2-3 minutes
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ EXTREMELY SAFE: One of safest calming points for all pediatric ages. Can use acupressure from birth. Teach parents for home use.

Location Description: Midpoint between medial ends of eyebrows (glabella)
Primary Indication: Insomnia, anxiety, headache, nasal congestion, calming children, reduce fear
Needling Depth: Child 3-8: 0.1-0.2 inch horizontal; Child 8-12: 0.15-0.3 inch horizontal; Teen: 0.2-0.4 inch horizontal
Technique: Horizontal subcutaneous threading toward hairline, or acupressure (pinching gently)
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ VERY SAFE: Excellent calming point. Acupressure very effective and safe from infancy. Parents can use at home during tantrums or before sleep.

Location Description: 2 cun above wrist crease, between tendons of palmaris longus and flexor carpi radialis
Primary Indication: Nausea, vomiting (especially chemo-induced), anxiety, chest discomfort, motion sickness
Age Recommendations: All ages; very safe and effective
Needling Depth: Infant: acupressure; Child 3-8: 0.2-0.3 inch; Child 8-12: 0.3-0.5 inch; Teen: 0.5-0.7 inch
Technique: Perpendicular insertion between tendons, or acupressure with firm pressure
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ SAFE: Extremely effective for nausea in pediatric oncology. Acupressure wristbands can be used continuously. Teach parents technique.

Location Description: In triangular fossa of ear, at apex
Primary Indication: Anxiety, insomnia, pain reduction, calming, ADHD support
Age Recommendations: Age 4+ for ear seeds; Age 8+ for needling
Needling Depth: Ear seeds preferred for children; Teen: 0.1-0.15 inch if needling
Technique: Ear seeds (vaccaria) taped in place for 3-7 days; press 3-5 times daily. Minimal needling in teens only
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ SAFE: Ear seeds are non-invasive and very safe for ages 4+. Teach child to press seeds when anxious. Replace weekly.

Location Description: On dorsum of hand, between 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones, at midpoint of 2nd metacarpal radial border
Primary Indication: Immune support, pain relief, fever, cold/flu prevention, general tonic, headache
Age Recommendations: Age 2+ for immune use; acupressure safe from birth
Needling Depth: Infant: acupressure; Child 2-6: 0.2-0.3 inch; Child 6-12: 0.3-0.5 inch; Teen: 0.5-0.7 inch
Technique: Perpendicular insertion toward 2nd metacarpal, or firm acupressure for 1-2 minutes
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ SAFE: Excellent general point for children. One of most used pediatric points. Contraindication: avoid strong stimulation in pregnancy (for practitioners).

Location Description: On midline of head, 7 cun above posterior hairline, at apex of skull
Primary Indication: Developmental delays, focus/concentration, dizziness, headache, prolapse, memory, ADHD
Age Recommendations: Age 3+ (after fontanelle closure); check fontanelle before needling
Needling Depth: Child 3-6: 0.1-0.2 inch horizontal; Child 6-12: 0.2-0.3 inch horizontal; Teen: 0.3-0.5 inch horizontal
Technique: Horizontal subcutaneous threading, very gentle. Acupressure or tapping with tool (shonishin) safe for younger
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ CRITICAL CHECK: NEVER needle if anterior fontanelle open (typically closes 12-18 months). Verify closure by palpation. Shallow horizontal needling only when safe.

Location Description: Four points 1 cun anterior, posterior, left and right of GV 20
Primary Indication: Brain development, cognitive function, focus, learning difficulties, developmental support
Needling Depth: Child 3-6: 0.1-0.2 inch horizontal; Child 6-12: 0.2-0.3 inch horizontal; Teen: 0.3-0.4 inch horizontal
Technique: Horizontal subcutaneous threading toward GV 20 from each of 4 directions, or acupressure
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ IMPORTANT: Same fontanelle precautions as GV 20. Verify anterior fontanelle closed before needling. Can use gentle tapping or acupressure earlier.

Primary Indication: General pediatric acupuncture safety by age
SAFETY WARNINGS: ğŸ‘¶ 0-2 years: Acupressure, shonishin, moxa primarily; avoid needling except emergency. ğŸ‘§ 2-4 years: Minimal needling, 2-4 points max, very fine needles. ğŸ‘¦ 4-8 years: Gentle needling, 3-5 points, prefer laser/acupressure. ğŸ§’ 8-12 years: Modified adult technique, 4-6 points. ğŸ‘¨ 12-18 years: Near-adult technique with sensitivity to privacy.

Primary Indication: Digestive disorders, colic, constipation, gas, abdominal pain
Age Recommendations: Birth to 12 years; excellent for infants
Technique: Gentle clockwise circular massage around navel, 50-100 circles, 2-3 times daily. Use oil or lotion. Can be done by parents
SAFETY WARNINGS: âœ“ VERY SAFE: Excellent alternative to needling in young children. Teach parents proper technique. Always clockwise direction. Gentle pressure appropriate to age.

Location Description: Various points, especially CV 8, ST 36, BL 20, BL 23
Primary Indication: Digestive weakness, immune support, chronic cold conditions, fatigue
Technique: Moxa on ginger slice, or stick moxa held 2-3 inches away. 3-5 minutes per point. Monitor skin closely
SAFETY WARNINGS: âš ï¸ BURN RISK: Never leave child unattended during moxa. Check skin temperature frequently. Remove immediately if too hot. Never use direct moxa on children. Parent must be present.
